twelve inches to the foot and
thirty six inches to the yard and things like that but uh i think uh from my work experience i found
i learned uh to use a rationalized system of measure which turned out to be the metric system
and an awful lot of the problems that we did on exams and our homework assignments and everything else involved converting
from uh English units or nonstandard units into this uh rationalized M K F system
and uh so i became quite accustomed to uh to a rationalized system and and used to making all the necessary conversions
and since then i have discovered uh other engineers are very prone to make mistakes
because they will pick up a textbook and uh and find some formula for solving a problem

and they fail to realize that the formula is expressed in the the rationalized M K F system and they'll proceed to plug in inches and feet and pounds and uh things like that and they come up with a funniest answers you ever you can imagine
and some of them don't realize that they've made a mistake and so uh you know a lot of energy and uh a lot of work and so forth uh goes into building something only to discover it doesn't work
i kind of agree that uh maybe ten on or twenty years ago we should have gone into a uh sort of a dual display arrangement where you know our our speed limit signs were
were sort of a double sign with a a big miles per hour and a little kilometers per hour type uh marking on the side
uh and little things like that i i notice in a lot of uh
uh technical literature that you pick up and catalogs and so forth that you will find the metric units expressed in parenthesis or sometimes the other way around the metric units are expressed first
and then the English equivalent that's uh is put into parenthesis for reference

you know i think also equally important is that uh it needs to be put into practice in in everyday life we're seeing a little bit of it now that you go out to work on your car and you discover your English wrenches don't fit

when you're solving a problem that if you're sitting there trying to uh establish a relationship with some physical system uh when you come up with your final formula if you analyze the units of measure they should come out right
and the the basic units of measure are are distance and time and mass and electric charge
and so if you convert all your measure into those uh fundamental units and analyze them you can uh get a pretty good sense as to whether your formula is correct
